message: Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont takes the oath of office from Vice President Biden to begin his new term on the first day of the 115th Congress.  Leahy is the Dean of the Senate and the incoming Vice Chairman of the Appropriations Committee.

Today the Senate Judiciary Committee held its first hearing of the 115th Congress – the confirmation hearings for the nomination of Senator Sessions to be Attorney General.  It was my honor to introduce Senator Feinstein as the new Ranking Member of the committee.  In its history, only six women have served on the Senate Judiciary Committee; three of those six are currently serving.  Today Senator Feinstein became the first woman to serve at a Judiciary Committee hearing as the Ranking Member, and we could not have a better leader than the leader we have in Senator Feinstein.

But after our hearings, after the written questions I have submitted to him, and after carefully reviewing his record, there still are far too many doubts.  Now, more than ever, we need an independent Attorney General — one who is committed to standing up for the constitutional and statutory rights of all Americans. Tomorrow (Tuesday) at about Noon, the Senate will vote on the nomination of Betsy DeVos for Secretary of Education.  I strongly oppose her confirmation because I do not believe that she is qualified for the job.  Universal free public schools were a revolutionary American invention.  Betsy DeVos fundamentally disagrees with the importance of public education.  I agree with the thousands of Vermonters who have contacted me about this nomination:  We need to strengthen public schools, not snub them. I will vote against this nomination tomorrow, and I hope that the Senate will rise to this important occasion to reject this choice. You can watch the Senate roll call live, at Noon, on CSPAN2.

I said what Majority Leader McConnell did was “not good for the country.  It’s not good for the United States Senate. It’s not good for democracy. And it sure as heck is not good for free speech.”  You can watch part of my Senate Floor speech HERE:  https://youtu.be/V6xToKCv3m0

As Republicans continue to rush through poorly considered Cabinet nominees, the Senate turned last evening to the nomination of Tom Price to be Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. Congressman Price has long been on a crusade to gut the foundations of America’s health system. From proposals to privatize Medicare and to cut Social Security, to block-granting Medicaid and repealing the Affordable Care Act, Representative Price’s complete disregard for the programs and resources that are working to bring vital health insurance and health care resources to millions of families is harmful to them, and it is disgraceful. Representative Price has also fought to diminish women’s health care and to abolish Planned Parenthood, threatening family planning services and a woman’s and her family’s right to make their own health decisions. And the allegations that he violated the STOCK Act, which prohibits lawmakers from using their role in Congress to make investment decisions, are particularly troubling. For these reasons, I strongly oppose his nomination, and I sincerely hope my friends in the Senate across the aisle will join in this effort. Read my full statement HERE: https://www.leahy.senate.gov/press/statement-of-senator-patrick-leahy-on-the-nomination-of-representative-tom-price-to-serve-as-secretary-of-the-department-of-health-and-human-services

Last night at 2 a.m., Senate Republicans pushed through the nomination of Tom Price to be Secretary of Health and Human Services, on a narrow party-line vote.  I cast my vote against this nomination for many reasons, but most important were the deep concerns I heard from Vermonters about what Congressman Price’s nomination would mean for their health and the health of their families.  Below is a word cloud reflecting many of those concerns.  If now-Secretary Price follows through on his long obsession with privatizing Medicare, block-granting Medicaid, and repealing the Affordable Care Act, millions of Americans will lose adequate health insurance coverage. That would be deeply harmful for families and individuals, for their communities and hospitals, for our overall health care system, and for the nation.

At 7 p.m. this evening, the Senate will vote on the nomination of Steve Mnuchin to be the Secretary of the Treasury. This nomination is another indication that, far from fulfilling his promise to “drain the swamp,” President Trump is filling his Cabinet with insiders like Mr. Mnuchin, who may understand the intricacies of Wall Street, but who knows shockingly little about the hardships faced on Main Street. After beginning his career at Goldman Sachs, Mr. Mnuchin rose to become known as the “Foreclosure King” because of the dubious practices such as “robo-signing” at OneWest Bank. During his testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, he failed to acknowledge these practices and also neglected to mention that he was a director of an offshore account worth more than $100 million. I cannot buy what he is selling, and neither can Vermonters. I urge the Senate to reject this nomination tonight. You can read my full statement on this nomination HERE: https://www.leahy.senate.gov/press/statement-of-senator-patrick-leahy-on-the-nomination-of-steven-mnuchin-to-be-secretary-of-the-treasury

This is the first Sunshine Week that the public’s right to know is under direct assault.  The press is not the “enemy of the people.”  Instead, it’s needed to shine sunlight into the dark corners of our democracy where we need it most.  Last year we passed my FOIA Improvement Act, which strengthened and modernized the Freedom of Information Act.  Beyond this FOIA progress, we must be vigilant in protecting our right to know in the face of an administration prone to exaggerations, outright falsehoods, and attacks on the free press.  Read my full column on this issue HERE: https://www.leahy.senate.gov/press/clouds-on-the-horizon-the-publics-right-to-know-is-under-attack

During Sunshine week, I have reflected on how so many of this administration’s nominees have misled Congress. All of us need to recommit ourselves to the principles of open government that have made our nation so strong and enduring. I plan on asking Judge Gorsuch (who was vetted and recommended by far-right special interest groups) many questions about his independence.  I urge him to be complete and truthful in his testimony.  These hearings are a precious opportunity for Americans to get a glimpse into the institution that protects their most essential rights.

The Trump budget that was released today is divorced from reality. It is not a serious proposal, but a budget by tweet, and runs contrary to the true interests of Vermont and the country. For instance the elimination of the LIHEAP program would deny 21,000 needy Vermont households the heating assistance they need during destructive winter storms. And slashing cuts to disease research, EPA cuts to Lake Champlain cleanup, and zeroing out funding for public broadcasting would all harm Vermonters. Watch my statement on why I oppose this unbalanced, politically driven budget, BELOW.

Below is a copy of the letter that I led to the Trump Organization and the Donald J. Trump Revocable Trust, asking for answers about each entity's financial relationship to the President. Though President Trump argued in January that he was "completely isolating himself from his business interests," recent reporting has contradicted this. This raises concerns about conflicts of interest and violations of the Constitution's Foreign Emoluments Clause. The Framers included the Emoluments Clause for a reason:  A president should not have divided loyalties.  No one, and no president, is above the law.

The President’s budget displays a fundamental lack of understanding of the role of government of, by and for the people in supporting the middle class, lifting up the most vulnerable among us and serving our values and interests as a nation.  We should be supporting opportunity and creating jobs, caring for veterans and promoting our health and the environment -- not recklessly slashing vital lifelines to the American people.  It has been, and continues to be, my goal to complete the appropriations process in the Senate the way it is supposed to be done.  Each of the 12 appropriations bills deserves debate and a vote on the Senate Floor in a bipartisan process.  That is in the best interests of the country, and I believe that Chairman Cochran shares this goal.  The President’s budget proposal is not bipartisan.  And it is not in the best interests of the country or of the real priorities of the American people.  It’s unbalanced, needlessly provocative and appallingly shortsighted.  It is not a pathway toward returning the Senate to doing its work the way it is supposed to be done. More than being dead on arrival, this budget is truly odious on arrival.    The appropriations process is where we set the nation’s spending priorities.  It is where priorities become more than concepts or promises or words; it is where they become real.  This is just the latest version of the President’s unbalanced priorities.  It is an unbalanced budget with serious and harmful consequences for our economy, for working families, for those who are struggling, for our environment, for health, and for our national security. This is not acceptable.    The power of the purse rests with Congress, and as Vice Chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee I intend to exercise that power.  I look forward to working with Chairman Cochran in laying a bipartisan path forward.  A path forward that returns the appropriations process to the way it should be done and produces bills that reflect our values as a nation.

In an address to the Senate today on the Senate Floor I reported on President Trump’s budget.  This unbalanced budget does not support working families or lift up the most vulnerable among us so that they can get on their feet.  We should not be recklessly slashing vital lifelines that help Americans with basic needs so they can lift themselves and their families onto paths of opportunity.  This budget particularly targets Rural America, in states like Vermont.  It would *literally* leave Vermonters in the cold by completely eliminating LIHEAP.  It would slash Medicaid funds that Vermont relies on to keep rural hospitals open.  It would force millions of children near poverty off health insurance.  All of this to fund a wall that doesn’t work and further benefit the very wealthiest in our society.  The power of the purse rests with Congress.  I pledge to work with Chairman Cochran to work toward the goal of passing all twelve appropriations bills, in an open, bipartisan process, that more accurately reflect the true values and needs of our nation.
This bill can’t be fixed.

The President’s proposed budget for the Department of Education can be summed up in one word: abysmal.  At our hearing today in the Senate Appropriations Committee, I shared with Secretary DeVos my grave concerns about the consequences that this budget would have on Vermont’s children, schools and communities.  This is a shortsighted, irresponsible and unrealistic budget proposal.  I will be working with committee members on both sides of the aisle toward the goal of crafting a budget that truly puts America – and America’s children – first.

ICYMI: The Washington Post breaks down Betsy DeVos’ testimony before the Labor, Health and Human Services Appropriations Subcommittee yesterday.  It is unacceptable for the Secretary of Education of the United States to refuse to offer assurances that our children will not be discriminated against in their schools.  As I clearly told her in this hearing, the Trump budget is abysmal.

Attorney General Sessions on Tuesday finally faced some serious questions, but he has continued to evade his responsibility to testify before the two Senate committees that have jurisdiction and oversight responsibilities over the Justice Department.  For the second time in just a few weeks, he abruptly cancelled his testimony before the Appropriations Committee, and he has not testified before the Judiciary Committee since he was confirmed.  It is disappointing that he was not completely forthcoming on Tuesday before the Intelligence Committee.  There is executive privilege, which must be invoked by the President, who has not invoked it in this case, and is not absolute.  There are also constitutional privileges such as the Fifth Amendment’s right to not incriminate oneself.  But there is no “I would rather not answer” privilege.  The American people, and the lawmakers who are conducting investigations into Russia’s influence in our election, need and deserve answers to these questions.  If he cannot distinguish between the public interest and President Trump’s interest, he will be unfit to serve as Attorney General.

President Trump’s budget for the Department of Health and Human Services undermines the Department’s very mission to protect the health and wellbeing of Americans.  When Secretary Price appeared before the Appropriations Committee today, I made it clear that the impact of this budget will have on Vermont’s and other American families is unacceptable.  For starters, the proposed budget cuts the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention by 17 percent, the National Institutes of Health -- which directs crucial medical research into cures and treatments for diseases from cancer to diabetes -- by 21 percent, and eliminates the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program, which many Vermonters rely on to survive Vermont’s winters.  And these draconian cuts are only the beginning.  I am also strongly opposed to Republican efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act and replace it with a bill that will insure millions fewer Americans and would slash Medicaid.  The cruel elements of the House Trumpcare bill penalize sick Americans, all to give massive tax breaks to special interests and the wealthiest among us.  We can’t be sure what the Senate Trumpcare bill will be like because Senate Republicans have decided to craft their legislation behind closed doors, forsaking bipartisanship and denying the American people the right to know what their representatives are working on.  Even the fact that they are hiding the bill and the process of writing it strongly signals that it is a very, very bad bill for the American people.   You can watch my words for Secretary Price below.

Join me LIVE as I announce the Voting Rights Advancement Act that I am introducing today with Representative Sewell and Representative Lewis.  I am introducing the Senate bill with 46 original cosponsors.  Our bill is a remedy to the Supreme Court’s Shelby County decision in 2013, which gutted a key provision of the Voting Rights Act.  Immediately after the Court acted, several states rushed to enact a raft of voter suppression laws.  For the sake of Americans’ fundamental right to vote, and for the sake of our democracy, Congress and the President need to join us in restoring the Voting Rights Act.

We’re finally seeing why Senate Republican leaders have been hiding their shameful Trumpcare bill for so long.  With no hearings, no debate, no vetting process, and no score, this plan breaks every promise the President made about what he would do in repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act.  Cobbled together behind closed doors, it is a cruel and cynical hoax, played on millions upon millions of Americans who would lose all or some of their health insurance protections under this plan.  Millions of Americans would not be able to afford insurance.  The driving principle in writing this travesty is not improving health insurance, a goal we all share.  The main goal is to free up funds to give another massive tax cut to the wealthiest Americans.  It is a huge tax cut for the rich, disguised as a health plan.  This bill would affect real people, real families, in Vermont and across the country.  This isn’t a political campaign.  This is about life, and death, and every family’s access to health care.   These enormous Medicaid cuts would have especially devastating effects in Vermont.  One in four adults in Vermont is covered by Medicaid.  Almost half of Vermont’s children rely on Medicaid or CHIP for basic health care.  Two in three nursing home residents receive Medicaid.  These are the most vulnerable Vermonters.  These are nursing home patients and their families, pregnant women, children, people with disabilities, and their families -- Vermonters working multiple jobs, but who still cannot afford health insurance.   Incredibly, this bill also undermines Vermont’s ability to fight the opioid crisis.  Vermont has done excellent work to cover comprehensive mental health and addiction treatment services under Medicaid, which would be at risk under this bill.    The bill also attacks women’s health by allowing states to choose what insurance plans have to cover, putting maternity benefits and other benefits at risk.  It tells women they cannot choose their providers by disallowing Medicaid reimbursement to Planned Parenthood clinics.    A true health care bill does not cut millions of Americans off health insurance.  A true health care bill does not allow insurance companies to charge people more for less coverage.    I will do all I can to prevent enactment of this disastrous plan, or anything that comes close to it.

Today I have the opportunity to question EPA Administrator Pruitt. I support a strong EPA, a well-funded and staffed EPA, and an effective EPA that supports our nation’s environmental quality while also supporting our economic wellbeing. Where this administration won’t stand up for clean water, healthy air, our climate, science-based decision making, and holding polluters accountable, I will stand up. I reject this shortsighted and reckless budget proposal from an administration that would rather bury its head in the sand about climate change, while it works to create chaos and an utter loss of staff morale at the EPA and other agencies. Watch my remarks LIVE here.
I am questioning Administrator Pruitt about the devastating effects that the Trump budget would have on our land, air and water.  Watch LIVE here.

Join U.S. Senate Democrats and me as we talk about the disastrous effects that Trumpcare will have on our constituents.  This is not about improving health insurance.  CBO estimates that 22 million Americans would lose insurance under this plan.  All so that Republicans can give a massive tax cut to the wealthiest people in America.  To illustrate the effect that this terrible bill will have on Vermonters, I will be holding a picture of my constituent Sam, who is only able to pursue his dream of becoming an artist because he can manage his Cystic Fibrosis through medication.  Yet this Trumpcare bill would allow states to deregulate the insurance market and deny people care for preexisting conditions.  Sam and so many others depend upon insurance coverage and the protections under the Affordable Care Act.  This bill cannot pass.

Merely delaying the vote vote on Trumpcare is not enough.  Senate Republicans should shelve this disastrously cruel plan -- for good.  It would take away health insurance from 22 million Americans and leave millions with less coverage, at higher costs.  These are decisions that literally mean health or illness and life or death to countless people.  This bill is about more than numbers:  It affects real people in Vermont and around the country.  I will oppose this cruel legislation in any form it takes.

This Muslim ban has nothing to do with safety and everything to do with Donald Trump’s discriminatory campaign promises to institute a “Muslim ban.”  In response to my questions, the President’s own top security officials have emphatically answered that nationality alone IS NOT a reliable indicator of terrorism.  I am disappointed that despite this expert testimony, the Trump administration has pursued this ban and the Supreme Court has allowed parts of it to take effect.  As the July Fourth weekend approaches, I have been reflecting on how America’s greatness has always been reflected by the spirit of Americans – both our independence and religious freedom.  Let me be clear: a Muslim ban is not American.  It goes against all of our country’s greatest traditions.

Senate Trumpcare 2.0 is just as bad as earlier versions and in some ways is worse.  This remains a stumbling, shameful and craven exercise to pass a tax bill in the guise of a health care bill.  The ‘mean’ House bill the President described keeps getting meaner.  Lost to many in the White House and on Capitol Hill is the fact that these are decisions that literally mean health or illness and life or death to countless people.  Not much is new in the latest Trumpcare bill.  It will still drop millions of Americans from Medicaid support – working families who are struggling, parents and grandparents in nursing homes, and families coping to care for members with disabilities.  It will make it harder for Americans with pre-existing conditions to find and buy insurance, and it will decimate Vermont’s ability to combat opioid and drug addiction.  It will inflate premiums and deductibles, particularly on older Americans, and will price millions of families and individuals out of being able to afford coverage.  It is way past time for Senate Republicans and this White House to stop this reckless exercise and work with us to find ways to bring lifesaving health care to more Americans, not to fewer families, as the Republican plan would do.    I will continue to strongly oppose this shameful proposal.  I hope those members on both sides of the political aisle who have previously spoken out in opposition to these proposals will stand firm.  Instead going behind closed doors to make health care harder to have, let’s work together to build on the successes of the Affordable Care Act and make it better.  Don’t undermine families’ access to insurance and the health care they need.

Senate Republicans have once again failed to craft a healthcare bill that will actually help sick Americans.  It is actually a tax bill in the guise of a health plan.  It should come as no surprise to anyone that this abomination of a bill, cobbled together behind closed doors, has fallen short under Leader McConnell’s hyper-partisan strategy.  What IS surprising is that even after it has become clear that the American people reject Republican efforts to rob them of their health insurance, Leader McConnell now wants to repeal the Affordable Care Act without a replacement, a proposal that the CBO has estimated would remove health insurance from 32 million Americans. This is bad politics and worse policy.  It would DIRECTLY hurt millions of Americans.  This morning, Leader McConnell said:  “These are not just numbers on a page, these are the lives of real people.”  I couldn’t agree more, and this plan puts the lives of thousands of Vermonters in jeopardy, which is why I will do all I can to defeat this latest disastrous plan.  It would drag our nation’s families back to the dark ages when Vermonters could be denied insurance for pre-existing conditions, and when health insurance was a privilege for the wealthy.  Repealing the Affordable Care Act would be a disaster for Vermonters and the nation.  The goal of these successive Republican plans is not, and never has been, to truly help people.  Join me in standing against these shameful tactics.

This was a lockstep vote for Trumpcare, produced through a secretive and shoddy process.  These decisions mean health or illness and life or death to countless Americans.  And let’s be clear:  Republican senators have no idea what they voted for with this motion to proceed.  Millions upon millions of Americans’ health is at stake.  This cynical vote is intended to lead to a final Trumpcare plan to kick millions of Americans off their insurance.  Trumpcare is a tax plan, disguised as a health plan, to slash hundreds of billions from the Medicaid help that is vital to millions of Americans.  We can improve healthcare, but not like this.  I’ve worked with Senator Shaheen and others to immediately stabilize insurance markets by making the cost sharing reduction payments permanent, and my bipartisan CREATES Act would lower prescription drug prices.  We also need to let Medicare negotiate lower drug costs.  In short, we need bipartisanship and regular order, not rash and disastrous legislation like this.

I joined Senator Donnelly and other Democrats today on the Senate Floor to try to prevent cuts to Medicaid as part of Trumpcare.  Medicaid supports insurance for pregnant women, children, individuals who have disabilities, and nursing and at home care for seniors.  Every bill we have seen Republicans propose includes deep cuts to this program.  Too many Vermonters and too many Americans rely on Medicaid.  We must kill this bill.

Next time you visit my office in the Russell Senate Office Building, take of note of the beautiful Vermont marble the building was built with.  On this day in 1906, a crane lowered a block of Vermont marble to start construction on what was to be called the Senate Office Building (later the Old Senate Office Building, and most recently the Russell Senate Office Building), where my staff and I work to represent Vermonters.  Some things never change though; the weather on that day 111 years ago was a scorching 90 degrees, so everyone’s glad that air conditioning was eventually added.  If you’re interested in more about the story, take a look at the This Day in Politics story below.

This morning Marcelle and I will go to Mass honoring the life of a dear friend who just died. At Mass we will also pray – as we have throughout the weekend – that America can remember that all people are equal.  There is no place in any great country for racial bias, religious bias or hatred of others.  The President should denounce David Duke and others who say they carry out racial hatred in his name.  I denounce it and as a Senator I will always denounce the racial, religious and even political bias and hatred growing in our country.  It makes us less safe as a nation and it is not why all of us work to preserve what we see as American values.  From peaceful Vermont my heart goes out to the people of Charlottesville and everywhere that people in America face hatred because of their race, religion or beliefs.  We must be better.
